label: Description
value: Brussels-style flounce with a central design of an eagle surmounted by a radiant sun, flanked by entwined initials and paired medallions containing the portraits of a man and woman. Above are crowns under canopies. Below are hearts pierced by arrows and chained together, lover's knots and initials. Probably made in 1695 for the marriage of Maximilian Emmanuel of Bavaria and Therese Cunegonde, daughter of John Sobieksi, the king of Poland.

label: Physical description
value: Medium: linen Technique: Brussels style bobbin lace

label: Credit line
value: Bequest of Richard Cranch Greenleaf in memory of his mother, Adeline Emma Greenleaf

label: Description
value: Small piece from a set of bed hangings, with an all-over pattern of off-set bees on a fine net ground. On the left side, a border of  lilies and their foliage. A scalloped edge is formed of gracefully curving laurel branches surrounding clusters of berries.

label: Physical description
value: Medium: linen Technique: needle lace with ground of loop and twist with twist return Label: linen needle lace

label: Provenance
value: This lace was once part of the border of a set of bed hangings said to have been ordered by Napoleon I for Josephine but which was most likely a gift to Marie Louise on the occasion of their marriage in 1810.

label: Provenance
value: Ex-collection: Marie Antionette. Madame Vigee LeBrun painted her wearing them in the portrait that is now in Versailles. The queen gave the lappets to one of her ladies – Marie Adrienne Potain de Bagueux on the occasion of her marriage in 1778 to the architect Pierre Rousseau.
